Title: Primary Medical Services for Basingstoke and Southampton
Description:
NHS England South (Wessex)  invites suitably qualified and experienced provider(s) to bid via an open tender process for the provision of Primary Medical Services, under the terms of APMS agreement(s), from 4 existing practices located as follows:

Bermuda Marlowe Practice (currently known as Marlowe Practice and Bermuda Practice), 
Shakespeare House Health Centre,
Shakespeare Road
Basingstoke
RG24 9DS

Adelaide GP Surgery, 
The Adelaide Health Centre
Western Community Hospital, 
William Macleod Way, 
Southampton, SO16 4XE

Nicholstown GP Surgery
Royal South Hants Hospital
Graham Road
Southampton SO14 0YG

Portswood Solent Surgery
7 Belmont Road
Portswood
Southampton SO17 2GD

The APMS agreement will relate to service provision to commence from 1 April 2016 for a contract period of 5 years; with the option to extend for an additional period of 5 years. The key objective of this procurement is to commission an able provider or providers through the most current NHS England Alternative Provider Medical Services (APMS) agreement form. The services must be performed by a GP-led primary care team and the Provider/s will be expected to:
 
•	deliver primary care services which will be safe, accessible, convenient and responsive 
•	design team-based services around the needs of patients and carers, ensuring they are offered more choice and a greater say in their treatment 
•	have processes in place to evaluate and continually improve on patient satisfaction 
•	have processes in place to engage effectively with the local communities
•	participate in the GMS Quality and Outcomes Framework (QOF) 
•	provide a range of Enhanced Services, remunerated in line with the relevant NHS Directions and specified by the buying organisation on an annual basis. 
•	adhere to any TUPE regulations in so far as these shall apply to each of the existing services
•	provide services 7 days per week, 365 days of the year between 08:00 to 20:00 from the Adelaide GP Surgery
•	provide services during core hours of 08:00 18:30, Monday to Friday excluding public holidays from the Basingstoke, Nicholstown and Portswood Solent surgeries whilst being prepared to contribute to the delivery of a seven-day service; should this be required locally in the future
•	provide a ‘Violent Patient’ service from all locations, which will be commissioned on a named patient basis, if required. 

To be considered to provide these services you must be able to demonstrate an effective track record of delivering NHS Primary Medical Services and have all appropriate registrations, including with the Care Quality Commission (CQC), in place at the time of service commencement.
The Contracts will be procured in Lots and the Values for each Lot are:
Lot 1 - £4,964,290 
Lot 2 - £2,853,091
Lot 3 –£1,801,713
Lot 4 - £1,818,482

Title: Provision of Domiciliary and Personal Care Services
Description: Halton Borough Council would like to invite expressions of interest from organisations on delivering high quality domiciliary and personal care to vulnerable adults in their own homes. Services will be for all adults with social care needs and organisations must demonstrate they are committed to delivering excellent care to people with an assessed need.Organisations must be registered with the Care Quality Commission (CQC) and demonstrate that they are capable of meeting the service specification whilst able to meet and exceed the quality standards set by the Council.The Council will be awarding a single supplier contract which will cover the whole of the Borough of Halton.It is proposed that the Provision will commence on 1st November 2017, and will run for an initial period of five (5) years with an option of two 12 month extensions.
Contact Address 1: Kingsway House c/o Municipal Building, Kingsway

Title: Care and Support for Patients with Complex Needs Living in their own Home
Description:
The services to be provided are care quality commission (CQC) registered care and support for adults and/or children and young people living in South Tyneside with complex health needs who qualify for NHS Continuing Health Care (CHC), Children's Continuing Care (CC) and Section 117 aftercare, living in their own home.
CHC packages of care are solely funded by the NHS to meet adults' (aged 18 and over) care needs which arise
from disability, accident or illness. This includes care needs arising from physical, mental health and learning disabilities.
Children and young people's continuing Care (CC) packages are solely funded by the NHS to meet children's needs which are identified as complex.
Section 117 (of the Mental Health Act 1983) packages of care are jointly funded through the local authority and NHS Clinical Commissioning Group to meet needs which reduce the likelihood of readmission to mental health hospital by being both proactive and/or reactive.

The contract is broken down into 7 lots, dependent on client group, and bidders may apply for 1 or more lots.

Applicants wishing to download the tender documentation must register as a supplier accessing the pro-contract website: https://procontract.due-north.com if you already have a login, select relevant opportunity, then login from the top right corner and enter your user name and password. If you are not registered select register free and complete the registration form. Your username and password will be e-mailed to you. To register interest against a contract select the NEPO portal from the 'narrow your results' section, then select the title of the tender within the opportunities section now select register button on that opportunity. If you have any queries or require further assistance, please contact Pro-Contract Email (ProContractSuppliers@proactis.com ).

Title: Supply of Emergency Care
Description:
The aim of the benefit is to allow employees to continue to attend work and carry out their duties when they would have otherwise had to take time off when their normal care provision has broken down (for example, childminder is ill).  This means that the provider must be able to quickly look at an employee's request and provide them with options.  
At a minimum the service must provide:
Emergency childcare (under 16), including:
	Nannies
	Nursery 
	Childminders
o	School Holiday Cover
	School holiday clubs
o	Adult care/ Elder care
	For anyone over the age of 16.  This could be for the employee themselves in some circumstances
	This should also include for elderly dependants, for example, parents who may have specific care requirements (for example, mobility problems, Alzheimer's)
•Care Standards:
All childcare and adult care providers used by the supplier will be appropriately regulated, licensed, reference checked and accredited.  In particular: 
o All Nurseries will be OFSTED registered with at least a 'satisfactory' grade
o All childminders will be members of the Professional Association of Childcare and Early Years (PACEY) and OFSTED/CSSIW registered.  Scottish childminders will be verified members of the Scottish Childminding Association and regulated by the Care Commission
o All nannies will be fully qualified, interviewed, reference checked, first aid trained, have relevant experience and possess an up to date enhanced Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) certificate;
All care agencies will be vetted by the Care Quality commission and/or the equivalent bodies in Scotland and Wales, and all care agencies used to provide the Services will have a rating of 'good' or 'excellent'.  All individual care workers will be interviewed, reference checked, first aid trained and possess an up to date enhanced Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) certificate and hold or be working towards NVQ level 2 or 3.
Data security is essential

Title: LPG5029 Healthwatch Tower Hamlets
Description:
The Health and Social Care Act 2012 requires each local authority to have in place a
local Healthwatch organisation. This organisation has the following statutory duties:

1.	Promoting and supporting the involvement of local people in the commissioning, the provision and scrutiny of local care services.
2.	Enabling local people to monitor the standard of provision of local care services and whether and how local care services could and ought to be improved.
3.	Obtaining the views of local people regarding their needs for, and experiences of, local care services and importantly to make these views known.
4.	Making reports and recommendations about how local care services could or ought to be improved. These should be directed to commissioners and providers of care services, and people responsible for managing or scrutinising local care services and shared with Healthwatch England.
5.	Providing information about local health and social care services to the public.
6.	Formulating views on the standard of provision and whether and how the local care services could and ought to be improved; and sharing these views with Healthwatch England.
7.	Making recommendations to Healthwatch England to advise the Care Quality Commission to conduct special reviews or investigations (or, where the circumstances justify doing so, making such recommendations direct to the CQC); and to make recommendations to Healthwatch England to publish reports about particular issues.
8.	Providing Healthwatch England with the intelligence and insight

Title: Healthwatch Hull
Description: Hull City Council invites qualified and interested suppliers to tender for the provision of a contract to secure a revised Local Healthwatch Offer in Hull, including the Independent Complaints and Advocacy Service (ICAS) - as required by law under the Health and Social Care Act, 2012. The Authority proposes to enter into a Contract for a maximum period of two years with the successful Tenderer (Service Provider), with an option to extend for a period or periods of up to a maximum of 12 months. Such extension will be at the discretion of the Council and subject to satisfactory performance. The anticipated service commencement date is 4 September 2017. The local Healthwatch enables patients, children and families, adult social care adults and wider public to have a local voice when accessing and experiencing health and social care services, for example GP practices, Hospital and care home settings. A new Service Specification has been developed as part of this new Tender, setting out the service requirements, including ensuring that the Local Healthwatch and ICAS services are accessible to all people across Hull, while meeting local needs and national expectations. There are seven statutory functions under the guidance from the Department of Health (DOH) and Local Government Association (LGA), relating to Healthwatch and ICAS, they are: Function 1 - Gathering views and understanding the experiences of people who use services, carers and the wider community. Function 2 - Making people's views known, including undertaking a level of Enter and View each year as set out within the service specification. Function 3 - Promoting and supporting the involvement of people in the commissioning and provision of local care services and how they are scrutinised. Function 4 - Recommending investigation or special reviews of services via Healthwatch England / Care Quality Commission (CQC). Function 5 - Providing advice and information about access to services and support for making informed choices. Function 6 - Making the views and experiences of people known to Healthwatch England and providing a steer to help it carry out its role as national champion. Function 7 - NHS Complaints Advocacy. The value of the new contract within the funding available through the DOH Local Reform and Community Voices grant 2017/18 would be a maximum of £166,385. Details of current expenditure or potential future uptake are given in good faith as a guide to past purchasing and current planning to assist you in submitting your Tender. They should not be interpreted as an undertaking to purchase any goods or services to any particular value and do not form part of the Contract. The Authority encourages consortia to deliver the contract for in order to provide value for money and the added value partnership working can bring. Under this contract the Supplier will be required to actively contribute to the achievement of social objectives. These include: skills development; employment an

Title: Residential and Nursing Care Home Services
Description:
Staffordshire County Council (the Council) has put in place a Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) arrangement for the provision of residential and nursing care home services for its clients. 

The Council has received applications to join the DPS from providers registered with the Care Quality Commission and has entered into a DPS Agreement for the provision of Residential and Nursing Care Home Services (the DPS Agreement) with each of the successful applicants in respect of one or more of ten lots.  The DPS arrangement will remain open up to 30 September 2019 with an option to extend for a further two years and the Council will continue to receive and consider applications to join the DPS until such closing date.   

The DPS is split into the ten (10) lots described below:

Lot: 1:  Residential - Older People
Lot 2:  Residential - Dementia
Lot 3:  Residential - Physical Disability / Sensory Impairment
Lot 4:  Residential - Learning Disability / Autistic Spectrum Disorder
Lot 5:  Residential - Mental Health
Lot 6:  Nursing - Older People
Lot 7:  Nursing - Dementia
Lot 8:  Nursing - Physical Disability / Sensory Impairment
Lot 9:  Nursing - Learning Disability / Autistic Spectrum Disorder
Lot 10: Nursing - Mental Health


Invitations to Tender for Call Off Contracts under the DPS Agreement commenced on 11 December 2017.

This Contract Award Notice relates to Call Off Contracts which have been awarded under the DPS Agreement with effect from 11 December 2018 to 10 March 2019 (inclusive).
Attachments: Care Home Awards 11.06.19 to 10.09.19.pdf

Title: Emergency Caretaker Primary Care Service Provision
Description:
Medina Medical Centre is a single-handed GP practice with 6,000+ registered patients in Dallow Ward, Luton.  Following an inspection by the Care Quality Commission (CQC), enforcement action was issued against the practice.  Consequently, Medina Medical Centre was formally served a Notice of Decision to suspend the Practice's registration for an initial period of four months, as of 27th September 2018, under section 31 of the Health & Social Care Act, 2008.  Due to the suspension of the Medina Medical Centre's CQC registration NHS Luton Clinical Commissioning Group (LCCG) were required to identify an Emergency Caretaker provider to deliver services with immediate effect, covering the duration of the suspension period. 

A competitive process was undertaken whereby all existing LCCG member GP Primary care practices  were asked for Expressions of Interest to provide caretaker services from The Medina Medical Centre site for an initial period of 4 months.  

The successful provider Practice will be required to provide all essential primary care services including Direct Enhanced Services, Home Visits and any other additional services as deemed appropriate throughout the core hours as determined in the NHS General Medical Services Regulations 2004 and subsequent amendments.  The successful Contractor will be expected to maintain the current service provision throughout core hours of 08:00am - 6:30pm and that GP/nurse appointments will be made available across all sessions.

All primary medical service providers are required to be registered with the CQC.
Additional Text:
There is a possibility that the contract may be extended, subject and dependent upon Care Quality Commission (CQC) requirements.  The CQC is the independent regulator of health and adult social care in England.  It seeks to ensure services are safe, effective, and compassionate and delivered to a high quality, encouraging services to improve. The inspection of general practice includes five key questions of services i.e. whether services are: safe, effective, caring, responsive to people's needs and well-led. CQC rates each of the five questions to give an overall rating for a practice, the rating categories used include: Outstanding, good, requires improvement and inadequate. These ratings and practice reports are available on the CQC website.

The successful provider will provide a multi-disciplinary service led and supported by GPs, as part of the integrated service delivery. The provider will provide sufficient capacity as regards appointments and skill-mix across core hours and must:

a)	commence treatment of patients potentially suffering from immediate and life-threatening conditions as soon as they present to the Practice
b)	ensure emergency GP appointments are made available on the same day, where clinically indicated;
c)	ensure appointment lengths are tailored to meet the clinical needs of patients.
d)	ensure a routine/non-urgent GP appointment is made available. 
e)	ensure a routine/non-urgent appointment with a nurse or any appropriate Health Care Professional. 
f)	provide urgent /non urgent phlebotomy appointments via the Local Phlebotomy Service and claim via the providers existing phlebotomy service.  
g)	provide appointments that can be booked in advance.
h)	ensure patients are able to book and cancel appointments on-line;
i)	ensure patients are able to request and repeat prescriptions within 3 working days, including a facility to request repeats on-line;
j)	provide access for patients to co-located services within the health community, e.g. the community nursing service;
k)	A Provider must ensure that for each of its registered patients (including those patients under the age of 16) there is assigned an accountable GP.

Inclusion in list of patients: armed forces personnel:
The Provider may, if its list of patients is open, include a serving member of the armed forces of the Crown who has received written authorisation from Defence Medical Services  to receive primary medical services from the Provider's practice; and living or working within the Provider's practice area during the period in respect of which that written authorisation is given.

Title: Adult Residential Care Block Contract(s)
Description:
Bracknell Forest Borough Council intends to award block contract(s) for residential care for adults, including people with dementia. The maximum number of care homes with block contracts will be four, with a maximum number of 20 beds.

Within the maximum of 20 beds, approximately four could be intermediate care beds. Organisations must be financially sound, having a minimum turnover of a least double the contract value of approx. £4m (over a five year period). The Council reserves the right to undertake any financial checks that they believe are appropriate. 

The contracts awarded will be for a minimum of three years and maximum of five years. Care Homes must meet the following criteria: 

• The care home must be within three miles of Bracknell Forest boundary. We would consider care homes slightly outside of this limit in the event that we can not meet our requirement within three miles. 

• The minimum number of beds in any one home will be five • We will not consider a fee higher than GBP(£)725 per week per bed for residential care, including for people with dementia. 

• For intermediate care provision, the service must be available within Bracknell Forest boundary. 

• We will not consider a fee higher than GBP(£)900 per week per bed for intermediate care provision. 

• The care home must be registered with Care Quality Commission (CQC).

 • Where a care home has been inspected by CQC, they must hold a minimum of a Good rating 

• The care home must not have any restrictions on placements by their host authority 

• The care home must be prepared to sign the Council's block contract terms for residential care. The anticipated contract start date is 1st September 2017.

This procurement process is being completed under the 'Light Touch Regime', governing 'Social and Other Specific Services' detailed in the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. Please note that contracts will be awarded without any further publication and that no further publication will be placed on the Tenders Electronic Daily website (OJEU) after this Contract notice. All care homes who express an interest and meet the minimum criteria will be considered.

If the Council receives multiple expressions of interest, selection will be based on price, location, building, facilities and occupancy plus others as appropriate. If you would like to be considered for this contract, please email Contracts.Team@Bracknell-Forest.gov.uk and briefly detail how you meet each of the criteria stated above. The last date for clarifications is midnight 18th June 2017. Final date for expressions of interest is noon Wednesday 28th June 2017.

The Council will not be held responsible for not communicating important information to any organisation who has not officially registered their interest on the South East Business Portal link below:

Title: MRC Emergency Care Provision
Description:
CLOSING TIME FOR BIDS IS 07/11/2016 11:00 HOURS. DO NOT APPLY DIRECTLY TO THE BUYER. To express your interest in this opportunity email ExpressionOfInterest@crowncommercial.gov.uk.
An emergency care benefit has been in place at the MRC since November 2014.   During this time uptake has increased as the scheme has become established and employees are more at ease with using the provision. The aim of the benefit is to allow employees to attend their workplace when they would have otherwise had to take time off when their normal care provision has broken down (for example, childminder is ill). This means that the provider must be able to quickly look at  an employee’s request and provide them with options.  Ultimately the employee will decide whether the options available to them are suitable. Due to the dispersed nature of the organisation the provider must have a good network of care options across the country that are reliable.
The MRC would seek to provide 6 ‘sessions’ of care provision in the first year but would like the flexibility to increase/decrease this as appropriate for the following year (to be agreed 3 months in advance).  This recognises that what defines a ‘session’ will depend on the type of care that has been requested by the employee and that the time spent at a nursery might be different to that of a child-minder.
The spend related to this contract will depend upon the amount of sessions required per employee.
MRC does not guarantee any employee usage of this contract .
The provider must be flexible, recognising that many instances of contact from employees will be in emergency situations when their normal care arrangements have broken down and will therefore need a quick turnaround and response.
Ability for employees to put forward their own care providers to be assessed and brought on board by the emergency provider.
Detailed data gathering practices for those who employees register to ensure accurate information is gathered in one place and then provided securely to the care provider when required.
Employees must be able to contact the provider to seek assistance and make emergency care arrangements outside of the standard working week (Monday – Friday; 9-5).  This must be at a minimum of between 7:30am – 7:00 pm
The online profile should show employees how many sessions they have used and how many they have remaining.
Employees should have the option of paying personally for the benefit once the MRC entitlement has been exhausted ( this will require the use of secure payment systems).
At a minimum the service must provide:
Emergency childcare (under 16), including: Nannies, Nursery, child-minders, School Holiday Cover, School holiday clubs, Adult care/ Elder care.
All childcare and adult care providers used by the supplier will be appropriately regulated, licensed, reference checked and accredited. All care agencies will be vetted by the Care Quality commission and/or the equivalent bodies in Scotland and Wales
Attachments: Bidder - Logging into Emptoris for the first time.docx PS16245 ITQ Invitation to Quote Questions .pdf PS16245 ITQ Invitation to Quote.pdf PS16245 AW5.2 Price Schedule.pdf

How to Apply:
As part of the strategic alliance between UK Shared Business Services Ltd (UK SBS) and Crown Commercial Service (CCS), UK SBS can use the CCS eSourcing Suite for future procurements. If you have not yet registered on the eSourcing Suite, this can be done online at https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk by following the link 'Register for CCS eSourcing'. Please note that, to register, you must have a valid DUNS number (as provided by Dun and Bradstreet) for the organisation which you are registering, who will be entering into a contract if invited to do so. Once you have registered on the eSourcing Suite, a registered user can express an interest for a specific procurement. This is done by emailing expressionofinterest@crowncommercial.gov.uk. Your email must clearly state: the name and reference for the procurement you wish to register for; the name of the registered Bidder; and the name and contact details for the registered individual sending the email. Crown Commercial Service will process the email and then enable the Bidder to access the procurement online via the e-Sourcing Suite. The registered user will receive a notification email to alert them once this has been done. The Sourcing documents can then be accessed on the eSourcing Suite at: https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk using the instructions detailed in the specification documents within Contracts Finder. As a user of the e-Sourcing Suite you will have access to Emptoris email messaging service which facilitates all messages sent to you and from you in relation to any specific RFX event. Please note it is your responsibility to access these emails on a regular basis to ensure you have sight of all relevant information. For technical assistance on use of the e-Sourcing Suite please contact Crown Commercial Service Helpdesk : Telephone: 0345 010 3503 Training documents to support Bidders utilise Emptoris CCS eSourcing are available in the Contracts Finder Tender documents section.

Title: CP1329-16(3) Supporting Independence
Description: Devon County Council is the Contracting Authority for CP1329-16(3) Supporting Independence as detailed in the Specifications contained in Schedules associated to the Invitation to Tender (ITT) Document for this tender opportunity. CP1329-16(3) Supporting Independence is a contract consisting of two Open Framework Agreements, each with subsequent entry points should the Authority take the permitted extension periods. The Authority intends to exercise its discretion to enter into Extension Period 2 of the above-mentioned contract and therefore will open an Entry Point to allow for: • New entrants onto the Supporting Independence Framework; • Tenderers who have previously submitted a Tender unsuccessfully, further opportunity to tender again; • Providers who are already on the Supporting Independence Framework will have an opportunity to re-submit prices should they wish (including providing prices for additional zones, increasing or decreasing existing prices) that have previously been submitted by submitting section E3 - Pricing Schedule for Lot 1, Lot 2 or Lots 1 and 2 by completing the Price or Zone Amendment Pro-forma. Each entry point will be a single stage procurement. This is procured under Part 2, Chapter 3, Section 7 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (PCR 2015) - Social and Other Specific Services (also known as 'the light touch regime') This procurement does not follow, in particular, any of the defined procedures of the PCR 2015 (even if there are similarities) but does seek to adhere to the best practice procurement principles of Openness, Transparency, Fairness and Equity. CP1329-16(3) Supporting Independence contract consists of two lots. Each lot will operate over the administrative boundary area of Devon County Council and each lot will be split into 8 further sub-lots or zones, herby known as Zones. This contract will provide support services to Service Users (either as part of a group or individually) that have an eligible and assessed care need(s) that sits outside of the criteria for regulated care as defined by the Care Quality Commission. Each lot will have an individual Open Framework agreement and will have subsequent Entry Points after the initial Contract Duration as detailed at A1 of the ITT. At each Entry Point the Procurement Process will be conducted by the Authority in accordance with the instructions as defined in the ITT. Each Lot will have a duration of 12 months, there are one possible extension period of 12 months remaining and an Entry point will proceed each possible extension period. See section 5 Additional details for further information.
Additional Text: The Authority has conducted a robust and thorough Impact Assessment which can be found at https://new.devon.gov.uk/impact/personalised-support-and-group-based-services-unregulated/ Lot 1 - Group Based Care and Support. This Lot will have 8 geographical Zones (the Zone represent geographical areas, Zone 1 - Bideford/Northam, Great Torrington and Holsworthy Zone 2 - Ilfracombe, Lynton/Lynmouth, Barnstaple, South Molton Zone 3 - Tiverton, Crediton, Cullompton Zone 4 - Exeter Zone 5 - Honiton, Sidmouth, Exmouth, Seaton Zone 6 - Newton Abbot, Totnes, Dartmouth Zone 7 - Tavistock, Ivybridge Zone 8 - Okehampton, Moretonhampstead, please see Schedule 1 of the ITT. Group based Care & Support will ensure that any person with eligible needs is able to choose from a selection of Providers that can ensure the Service User is able to meet their defined 'My Care and Support Plan' outcomes. For information on how Individual packages support will be Called Off please see - Schedule 2 of the ITT. Lot 2 - Individualised Care and Support. This lot will have 8 geographical Zones, Zone 1 - Bideford/Northam, Great Torrington and Holsworthy Zone 2 - Ilfracombe, Lynton/Lynmouth, Barnstaple, South Molton Zone 3 - Tiverton, Crediton, Cullompton Zone 4 - Exeter Zone 5 - Honiton, Sidmouth, Exmouth, Seaton Zone 6 - Newton Abbot, Totnes, Dartmouth Zone 7 - Tavistock, Ivybridge Zone 8 - Okehampton, Moretonhampstead, please see Schedule 4 of the ITT. Individualised Support will ensure that any person with eligible needs is able to receive one to one support to ensure the Service User is able to meet their defined care plan outcomes. For information on how Individual packages support will be Called Off please see - Schedule 5 of the ITT. Tenderers may submit a Tender Response for any Zone(s) within Lot 1, Lot 2 or Lots 1 and 2. Tenderer Event There will be a Tenderer event held in Exeter, Devon County Council, County Hall on 1st April 2019 10am -12pm in relation to this Tender. The event will be focussing on the Tender Process and will explain the ITT and the other documents as well as useful information to enable Tenderers to be 'tender ready'. There will be an overview of the service requirement from commissioners of the service and there will be an opportunity to ask questions at the end of the event. Whilst every endeavour will be made to answer questions at this event, it may be necessary to respond at a later date. The presentations and questions and answers given will be made available via ProContract. Spaces for this event are limited and restricted to a maximum of two persons per organisation. To ensure that this event is of the most benefit, tendering organisations are encouraged to ensure that persons attending are the most appropriate i.e. persons who will be constructing and making decisions about any tender submitted. In order to book a place, please e-mail procurementpeople-mailbox@devon.gov.uk.

Title: YAS 178 2017_18 Occupational Health & Wellbeing Provision - AWARD
Description:
Provide a standardised Occupational Health (OH) Service in all its elements across the Yorkshire Ambulance Service (YAS), including standardising the reporting and provision of management information.
      o Support easily accessible high-quality services for staff employed within the full Trust geographical settings.
      o Support cost effective and efficient provision.
      o Prevent where possible and / or reduce the potential for ill health arising because of work done or the conditions / environment in which work is done / carried out.
      o Assist the appropriate placement of workers in work, considering their physical and mental health.
      o Promote the establishment and maintenance of the high standards of physical and mental health and wellbeing as a proactive process within the workforce and organisational culture, based on the international, national and local guidance and recommendations from World Health Organisation (WHO), International Labour Organisation (ILO), Commissioning for Quality & Innovation (CQUIN), National Institute of Clinical Excellence (NICE) (NG13), Care Quality Commission (CQC), National Health Service England (NHSE) and Public Health England (PHE) etc.
      o Increase the level of protection to the public and patients arising because of ill health or infection in YAS employees where relevant.
      o Promote Infection Prevention and Control within the work force and respond to such outbreaks / infections or disease that are relevant with speed and timely support, e.g. when informed of a community measles outbreak or pandemic, scabies in staff etc.
      o Increase the effectiveness of the organisation by supporting activities to enhance staff and organisational performance and morale through reducing risks at work that lead to ill health, staff absence and accidents.
      o Provide access to relevant services, for all employees and volunteers to appropriate and timely support and advice where required and relevant to role and remit; providing for physical and mental health needs.

Title: Design and Development of Talent Management Toolkit
Description:
Following on from the Rose Review, Better Leadership for Tomorrow (2015) significant attention has been given to the talent management (TM) agenda within the NHS. 

In 2016, the NHS National Improvement and Leadership Development Strategic Framework, Developing People - Improving Care was published. This framework represents a vision for improvement, leadership and talent management within the health and social care sector and seeks to guide action on skill building, leadership development and talent management for people in NHS funded roles. 

Additionally, the Care Quality Commission Well Led Framework reviews the governance and leadership effectiveness of NHS providers. It asks the question of providers 'Are services well-led?' and focuses on key elements such as leadership capability and capacity, engagement and culture. The framework was updated in 2017 and now also seeks NHS provider organisations to demonstrate and evidence their approach and
commitment to talent management, focusing on areas such as succession planning, career development and the quality of appraisals.
Additional Text: not applicable
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Silvermaple|SO167JQ|NONE||Yes|No]

Title: P0566 - Delivery of Healthwatch Birmingham Services - AWARD
Description:
The Council wishes to establish a Contract for the Delivery of Healthwatch Birmingham Service. The Health and Social Care Act 2012 amended the Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007 (the Act) to create a new consumer champion for health and social care services in the form of Healthwatch. The Healthwatch Birmingham service will play a vital role in improving health and social care services in Birmingham, as well as working with the local health and social care system to develop the areas identified as part of the recent Care Quality Commission review.  There is a clear opportunity to develop the voice of the citizen locally ensuring that services are robust, provided at the right time, in the way that meets the needs of citizens.  The focus will be supporting citizens to remain in their own homes and communities developing the support networks to enhance their lives.  Supporting the area of improvement to enable public engagement in shaping the future of the health and social care system in a systematic and joined up approach. Note that he Council is Procuring a contract for these services for itself only. 
      
      Healthwatch Birmingham will:
      
      •  Be an effective, powerful and independent local voice for the people of Birmingham;
      •  Promote better outcomes for both adults and children in health; 
      •  Promote better outcomes for both adults and children in social care;
      •  Be representative of the diverse communities within Birmingham; and
      •  Demonstrate it has the appropriate level of skills competencies required to deliver its functions to the highest possible level.
      
      The Contract will last for 3 years with the provision to extend for up to an additional 2 years subject to requirements and satisfactory performance.
      
      Registration and use of in-tend is free. All correspondence for this procurement process must be via the in-tend correspondence function. If you are unable to register with in-tend please either email us at cps@birmingham.gov.uk or call 0121 464 8000. 
      
      If you are interested in tendering please click on the following link to access the Council's tender Portal:-. https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register as a bidder. We will send you a log on and password so you can download the tender documentation. 
      
      Your completed tender documentation should be returned by noon on 18th February 2019 via the 'in-tend' system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc

Title: Cambridgeshire Extra Care Schemes
Description: Extra care housing is defined as specialist accommodation designed to maximise the independence of older people by providing a safe, secure and stimulating environment. Service Users retain the independence of having their own home and at the same time benefit from the availability of around the clock social care and housing support. The care and support service is expected to enable Service Users to live independently and to maximise the Service Users capacity to carry out tasks themselves. The service is divided into 4 Lots (schemes), The Authority wishes to appoint a single Provider per Lot to provide Extra Care services. Potential Providers can bid for more than Lot and will be awarded each Lot for which they are considered to be the Preferred Provider according to the evaluation process. It is expected that an initial contract will last for a period of 4 years. In providing the Services the Provider is required to be registered with the Care Quality Commission (CQC) and to maintain that registration throughout the Contract Period. Please ensure that you have made a copy of this advert and any relevant information or documents BEFORE the 'Document Available Until' date, this advert will not be accessible on or after this date. You then have until the 'Submission Return By' date to respond.

Title: 3164_18 - Carers Community Respite Services
Description:
In this present instance, ESPO is working on behalf of Leicestershire County Council (the Council) to undertake a procurement to refresh the open framework established 1st May 2015 for the delivery of community respite services for carers in Leicestershire.  

The service is for eligible (as assessed by the Council) Carers who look after a friend or relative who has an illness or disability and where the carer is unable to leave the cared for person.  

The Council wishes to refresh the framework to allow new service providers to join who can offer flexible respite care, in which the cared-for person can be supported at home or in the community in order to provide a break for the Carer at a time and in the way which best suits them.  

The aim of the Carers Community Respite Service is to make a positive difference to the lives of carers of adults in Leicestershire, and to sustain carers who have complex caring responsibilities due to their personal circumstances and those who they care for.

Required: Care Quality Commission registration (tenderers applying for providing Service B category only).

No specific lots, but tenderers can indicate which area(s) they are able to service - LCC and its seven Borough/District councils.

Appointed Framework providers will be added to the available call off list which includes providers appointed from the original 2015 procurement and the 2016 and 2017 Refreshes.

Title: SOL - Healthwatch Services 2020 - AWARD
Description:
Solihull MBC is looking to implement a contract for the provision of a Healthwatch Service in the borough of Solihull to a single supplier.
      
      The contract is to be for 3 years starting on 1st July 2020 with the option to extend for 1 + 1 years.
      
      The contract is required to deliver the seven functions of Healthwatch as described in the service specification, for the borough of Solihull. 
      o Gathering views and understanding the experiences of people who use services, carers and the wider community
      o Making people's views known
      o Promoting and supporting the involvement of people in the commissioning and provision of local care services and how they are scrutinised
      o Recommending investigation or special review of services via Healthwatch England or directly to the Care Quality Commission (CQC)
      o Providing information (signposting) about access to services and support for making informed choices
      o Making the views and experiences of people known to Healthwatch England (and to other local Healthwatch organisations), and providing a steer to help it carry out its role as national champion
      o NHS Complaints Advocacy identification and signposting

Title: Intermediate Nursing Care Provision
Description:
The contract is awarded under the Negotiation Procedure without prior publication in line with requirements as competition was absent for technical reasons (Regulation 32 (2) (b)(ii). The Council believes that the reasons for the use of this procedure have been met due to the paucity of registered nursing homes in borough, and indeed nationally.
Currently there are only 2 nursing homes registered by the Care Quality Commission in borough that is, this one and another, which is presently not in position to deliver this provision. The contract will deliver Intermediate specialist nursing care services. Access to and the efficacy of, Intermediate nursing care provision is reliant on community health professionals, within a multi-disciplinary team. The criteria for which is residence and registration with an in-borough GP, which would preclude use of out of borough provision as well as, lead to the loss of rehabilitative input which is the crucial element of this service

Title: CP1329-16 - Supporting Independence
Description:
CP1329-16 Supporting Independence contract consists of 2 lots. Each lot will operate over the administrative area of Devon County Council and each lot will be split into 8 further sub-lots or zones, hereby known as Zones.
Lot 1 - Group Based Care & Support Open Framework Agreement
Zone 1 - Bideford/Northam, Great Torrington and Holsworthy
Zone 2 - Ilfracombe, Lynton/Lynmouth, Barnstaple, South Molton
Zone 3 - Tiverton, Crediton, Cullompton
Zone 4 - Exeter
Zone 5 - Honiton, Sidmouth, Exmouth, Seaton
Zone 6 - Newton Abbot, Totnes, Dartmouth
Zone 7 - Tavistock, Ivybridge
Zone 8 - Okehampton, Moretonhampstead

Lot 2 - Individualised Care & Support Open Framework Agreement
Zone 1 - Bideford/Northam, Great Torrington and Holsworthy
Zone 2 - Ilfracombe, Lynton/Lynmouth, Barnstaple, South Molton
Zone 3 - Tiverton, Crediton, Cullompton
Zone 4 - Exeter
Zone 5 - Honiton, Sidmouth, Exmouth, Seaton
Zone 6 - Newton Abbot, Totnes, Dartmouth
Zone 7 - Tavistock, Ivybridge
Zone 8 - Okehampton, Moretonhampstead
This contract will provide support services to Service Users (either as part of a group or individually) that have an eligible and assessed care need(s) that sits outside of the criteria for regulated care as defined by the Care Quality Commission.

Each lot will have it's individual Open Framework agreement and will have subsequent Entry Points after the initial Contract Duration.

The procurement involves the establishment of a framework agreement. Framework agreement with several operators.

There are 3 possible extension periods available. Extension Period 1 = 12 months, Extension Period 2 = 12 months and Extension Period 3 = 12 months. Including the above (initial) duration of the framework this makes the maximum possible framework duration 48 months.

The provision of registered residential care for older men with long term alcohol misuse needs and a history of homelessness in the London Borough of Islington.

The service is registered with the Care Quality Commission (CQC).

Title: AS09719 Fareham LD Services
Description: This notice of contract award is for the purpose of transparency only and applies to the award of a contract for the provision of registered residential care services in the Fareham area within Hampshire, supporting people with learning disabilities for a period of up to 12 months. This followed serving of notice by the previous incumbent provider and the urgent need to ensure service continuity to the vulnerable client group (adults with learning disabilities). The contracted capacity is for 10 units. Service provision will be delivered in accordance with the Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014.The contracted hours incorporating sleep-ins equates to 488 for the service provision as a whole.

Title: PP17030 - Shared Lives Service
Description:
'Shared Lives' is non-residential / nursing care, delivered in the community, sharing the home of a 'Shared Lives' Carer. 

Shared Lives supports people over the age of 18 who following an assessment of need require long term support and accommodation, this support is delivered in a highly bespoke way.  

Providers are required to; as prescribed by the Care Quality Commission under their Fundamental Standards.
-Recruit, select and manage appropriate staff to develop and deliver the Wolverhampton Shared Lives Scheme
-Recruit carers and ensure they are appropriately trained and supported to acquire the skills to become and appropriately skilled Shared Lives Carer
-Carry out a full assessment to ensure suitability to become and Shared Lives Carer
-Ensure compatibility between the customer and the Shared Lives Carer
-Ensure all Shared Lives Carers are adequately trained to perform their duties to the required standard.

Title: (NU/1143)  The Provision of Non-Medical Help Support to Students
Description:
The scope of this contract is to provide non-medical help to cover support for which Disabled Students’ Allowance is being withdrawn to enable students with a disability to access the learning environment at Newcastle University. Support will be delivered primarily on Newcastle University premises. 

Lot 1: This will be a blended Study Assistant role that includes practical and mobility support, note taking (manual and typed), examination support with reader and/or scribe, laboratory support and study assistant.

Lot 2:  This will be a blended Support Assistant role to work with students with mobility difficulties and those who may arrive at university with personal care requirements.  The Support Assistant role includes practical and mobility support, note taking (manual and typed), examination support with reader and/or scribe, lab support and study assistant. Suppliers must be registered with the Care Quality Commission.

The successful supplier will recruit, supply and manage appropriately trained support staff with an enhanced DBS disclosure to deliver non-medical help services between Monday and Saturday, and between the hours of 9am and 7pm depending on demand. The agreement will be for up to 50 weeks per year to deliver non-medical help to students.  Support workers will be expected to work with new and continuing students at undergraduate and postgraduate levels of study.

Title: Executive Search & Selection - Appointments
Description:
This is notification that the Department is running an Ojeu Open Procurement for the services described. – (for which see ITT ref number 60207).
Interested suppliers need to register on the BMS system if they have not done so already. Details of registration can be found on the attached document and link provided.
The DH Appointments Team manages the recruitment and selection process for Public Appointments that are made by the Secretary of State for Health. Ministers decide on whether or not to use executive search for these appointments and decisions are made on a case by case basis, dependent on the profile of the appointment and challenges to recruitment of a particular post. Our appointments include high profile Chair and Non-Executive Director appointments to DH’s Arms-Length Bodies, including for example, NHS England, NHS Improvement and the Care Quality Commission. To ensure open competitions attract the very best candidates and a wide and diverse field of applicants and for some campaigns target specialist groups, there is sometimes a need to use executive search to support a campaign. The Department of Health is looking for an organisation to provide primarily, executive search support for key public appointments. Support may also be required for any other appointment for which Ministers have an interest and agree that search support from the DH contract may be used. The Department’s default position is not to use executive search when recruiting to public appointment. This also reflects the Government’s general view, and the Minister for the Cabinet Office (whose permission to use Executive Search is required) will only agree to the limited use of search. However, there are occasions when Ministers may, as part of the wider recruitment process, choose to use executive search support to strengthen the candidate field. This can be particularly important for key national roles, for certain specialist roles and for engaging with hard to reach groups, where even targeted advertising and use of social media can have limited effect. Search can be particularly effective in engaging with senior figures in the commercial/private sector and generally with those whose experience is out of the health and social care sector. The proposes Contract is expected to be for a period of up to 12 months, with two optional extension periods of up-to a further 12 months each. Please see attached  Procurement documents. DH reserves the right to not proceed to Contract for this requirement.

Title: Understanding regulatory approaches to telemedicine
Description: This research aims to understand how UK healthcare regulators (e.g. the Care Quality Commission (CQC) and the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)) and regulators in overseas countries (i.e. Canada, the United States of America, Australia, New Zealand or European member states) regulate doctors, other healthcare providers (e.g. pharmacists) and healthcare services, where the services are provided remotely. That is, when the individual providing the service is in a different physical location to the patient receiving the service.

Title: 170727 - Bullying & Harassment Training
Description:
The Trust has recently undertaken a Cultural Audit which over 1,750 staff responded to.  The themes identified as having the most extensive and detrimental impact on individual and organisational well-being included:

•	Unsupportive leader/manager behaviour
•	Violence and aggression; internal and/or external behaviour

Key themes taken from the staff survey which the Trust is focusing on as identified in the survey include:

•	Tackling bullying and harassment
•	Protecting our staff from abuse

The Trust's most recent report from the Care Quality Commission (CQC) identified:

•	There were allegations of bullying in some parts of the Trust.

Much work on improving the culture of the organisation has been undertaken to date to address the concerns of staff.

Several strategies have also been launched to provide support to staff and to identify what is required from the leaders within the Trust; Engagement Strategy, Leadership Strategy and Leadership Charter have been launched which align to the national NHS Healthcare Leadership Model, setting out the leadership behaviours we expect all of our leaders to demonstrate a Health and Well-being Strategy.

To further address the concerns raised in regard to bullying and harassment the Trust has produced an action plan and is looking for some elements of the plan to be provided from an external source.  These elements will be used and maintained by the Trust in the future.

Title: Support for the National Forum of People with Learning Disabilities & the National Valuing Families Forum (2015-2017)
Description:
A number of services will be delivered through the contract including the provision of governance, facilitation, administration and enabling services for the two Fora.

The key outcomes are:
1) People with learning disabilities and family carers are effectively involved and their voices heard from local and regional to national level in policy making and planning and oversight of services for people with learning disabilities and their families
2) Government, and key statutory bodies/ delivery agencies are able to consult effectively with people with learning disabilities and their families on issues affecting them
3) People with learning disabilities and family carers coordinate and share information on their involvement in related activities such as engagement with Health and Wellbeing Boards, NHS England, Healthwatch and the Care Quality Commission
4) The governance and administrative arrangements of the Fora are compliant with best practice standards in the third sector around integrity, transparency and accountability
5) The Fora become more organically sustainable bodies.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and the Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West
